overview.short: Cronobacter species are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic Enterobacterales that are opportunistic pathogens, best known for association with powdered infant formula contamination and invasive neonatal infections.
overview.clinical_context: Can cause neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and necrotizing enterocolitis; also opportunistic infections in immunocompromised adults.

field_notes.Lactose Fermentation: Often variable or delayed; some strains appear weakly lactose-positive on MacConkey Agar.
field_notes.Motility: Typically motile with peritrichous flagella, but some isolates may appear weakly motile depending on conditions.
field_notes.Growth Temperature: Many isolates grow at lower temperatures than typical Enterobacterales; growth at ~6–10°C is reported for some strains and may support food-associated persistence.

key_differentiators.notes: ONPG positivity supports a lactose-delayed/β-galactosidase-positive Enterobacterales rather than classic ONPG-negative genera.
Oxidase negativity supports Enterobacterales and helps exclude oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods.
Citrate positivity supports Cronobacter/Enterobacter-like profiles rather than typical E. coli.

common_confusions.reason: Strong overlap in citrate/VP positivity and broad sugar fermentation patterns within Enterobacterales.
Some isolates can appear lactose-positive and mucoid, overlapping with Klebsiella phenotypes.
Citrate positivity and variable sugar reactions can overlap; species-level resolution often requires panels or MALDI-TOF.

when_to_question_identification: Oxidase positivity argues against Cronobacter (suggests Aeromonas/Vibrio/Pseudomonas-type organisms).
H2S production argues against Cronobacter and suggests Salmonella/Citrobacter freundii complex possibilities.
Non-motile isolate with strong capsule and consistent lactose positivity may suggest Klebsiella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Useful Enterobacterales biochemical panel to support genus/species identification.
Rapid and reliable identification within Enterobacterales when biochemical overlap is high.
Selective/differential support for Cronobacter from food/infant formula contexts.
